dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavish nightclub with leafy tables and booths built int the branches of a huge tree. The stage is the ledge of a gothic cathedral, framed by two gargoyles. The decor suggests a Deco 430s speakeasy. Now Mack takes center sta

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Sure, I_ know early birds Catch all the worms -- But what kinda squirrelly birds Want breakfast that squirms? I'd rather dine with the...

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Nightbirds! If dayltg ght's too bright, birds, And blue skies make va blue (Boo hoo hoo) -- You just might, bir Be nightbirds, too! APPLAUSE as the Nightingales pose. A scenic curtain falls featuring a farm with crowing rooster. Mack takes the mic

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: (Elvis) “Thank you, thank y’ very much.” As you know, someone very special is making his debut here tonight. (imitates OWL) “Whooo? Whooo?” Oh, the owls are getting impatient, I’1l tell you who -- Kid Bantam, that’s who! (imitates HEN) “Cluck-uck-uck-uck-bakaw!"” Listen to those hens, they love him -- staying up late, huh, ladies? Okay, don’t get your eggs in a scramble. (off loony LAUGHS in crowd) Hoo-boy, the loons are out tonight--“Hoo- hoo-hoo-hoo-hoooe!” Now lemme tell you a little about the Kid. You know his real name? First time I met him, I ask “What’s your name?” And he says, “dagnabbit, shuddup!” So I say, hey, shuddup yourself, I’m just asking. And he says, get this _- “No, that’s my name - - Dagnabbit Shuddup! Anyway, that’s what the farmer calls me.” Kid you not. True etary  From the farmyard scene on the curtain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real farmyard scene. The mailbox reads “FARMER FAMILY FARM. All the lights are off in the ramshackle farmhouse, and the henhouse next to it. A COW dozes with a DONKEY, P sleep together, the night is quiet. Then... Rooster DAG pops into frame, CROWING.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Brakakakak! Brakakakak! Erkakakak-aroo! His chest swells -- his throat puffs -- his wattle wobble he blasts his brassy jazz riff into the silent night.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Er-er-roooo, ba-kak! Er-roooo, ba-kak! Er-roo bak-kak-kak-kak-kak! The night starts to respond, As Dag’s crow wakes them up, the animals start to complain...

dialogues.speaker: COW/DONKEY/PIGS
dialogues.text: Oooooocooch.... Yawwwwwwww.... Roink! Somewhere, a dog starts to HOWL. Other DOGS join in. A light comes on in the henhouse doorway. PENNY emerges - the cutest little chick you ever saw -- wide awake and ey sparkling as she listens to Dag crow. Older HENS appear behind her, squinting, groggy and grumpy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HEN
dialogues.text: Get back to bed. Don’t encourage him. Now a CRYING BABY adds his voice to the cacophony -- and LIGHTS start going on in the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Brakaka-kak, a rooo! Brak..

dialogues.speaker: FARMER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dagnabbit! Shuddup! Dag’s in musical seventh-heaven, so he doesn’t see the BO hurled out of the farmhouse window behind him... which CO him in the head, silencing him in mid-song.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Bak-kak-kak---unk! Dag sprawls, knocked unconscious. Penny moves to help -- then retreats as... THE FARMER stomps out of the house in his long-johns with length of twine in his hands. He kneels by Dag and loops knotted twin around his beak -- an improvised muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Last chance, Dagnabbit. He turns back to the house as Dag woozily comes around.. see he’s muzzled. Dag FREAKS OUT. He strains against the twine, trying to crow -- but he can only CROAK miserably.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Melp! Melp... Penny rushes to help, pecks at the muzzle. Dag pulls away

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, I’m not gonna kiss you. But Dag’s lovestruck eyes tell us that’s the last thing h worried about. He lets Penny bite his muzzle -- they both twist and pull -- and after an awkwardly intimate moment. Penny pulls the muzzle off! Dag CROWS in delight.

dialogues.speaker: ERK-ERK-A-ROO
dialogues.text: (catches himself, whispers) Erk-erk-a-roo. The noise brings the older hens back to the henhouse door HENS. Keep it down! Knock it off! Go to bed, ya freaks!

dialogues.speaker: OLD HEN
dialogues.text: Better yet -- fly the coop! Then we can all get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You think we want to be up all night? it’s just how we are.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HEN
dialogues.text: (righteous sniff) No better than nightbirds. The hens drift back to bed. Penny helps Dag up.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Boy, he really threw the book at you.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Aaah, I’m okay. But how ‘bout you? still getting henpecked?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You should hear what they say about you.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Maybe they’re right. Maybe we should fly the coop.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Only problem with that? We can’t fly.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: We could leave.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You mean... cross the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: But... why?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Why not? See what’s on the other side?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's it? That’s your plan? “We’ll see when we get there?” “men” Roosters. ‘No idea where they’re going, and won’t even ask how to get there. Well, til you get a little more specific about your intentions, you can just cross that road by yourself, mister.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Come on, Penny, don’t be so human.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m not human! It’s just -- when I cross the road with a guy, I wanna know what’s on the other sidé. You get back to me when you figure out where you’re going.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Where we’re going. She smiles, softening. They nestle a little closer. Dag CROWS a soft arpeggio, sings: ("If I Could Fly”)

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Talk about boring, everyone's snoring, It's not even ha past’ eight...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: And here we are, staying up late Again...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Everyone's always peckin'’ and pickin’ --

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: “Well, she's an odd duck..."

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: “Man, he's one funky chicken."

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I wish we could up and take flight To wherever birds stay up all night!

dialogues.speaker: DAG PENNY
dialogues.text: If I could fly, (spoken) I'd say goodbye... Why?!

dialogues.speaker: DAG PENNY
dialogues.text: To everyone but you. Whew.

dialogues.speaker: D. PENNY
dialogues.text: If I could fly, Hey! I'd fly away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To find us a home somewhere Ooh... new.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: A home somewhere far, Where we'll be who we are...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Where we'll rest in our nest all day... Where we’ iP Sta up and play Til the night fades away...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: And who gives a hoot What the other birds say! If we could fl We'd fly toget. er, Birds of a feather Across the sky, To someplace free... If only we Could fly. Penny’s eyes sparkle. Dag draws close. MUSIC continues under. They’re just about to kiss when... CONK! A package drops on Dash’s head. He spins and stumbles to the ground MUSIC stops. Penny rushes to help Dag up.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Ow! Man, I am having a bad head day. ON THE PACKAGE - which has ripped open when it hit the ground. Dag reaches down to pull out... A SOUVENIR SNOWGLOBE with a city skyline. Dag shakes it. REVERSE SHOT - Dag and Penny’s eyes are huge in the round glass, as they watch glitter swirl around the tiny city.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s snowing! I mean out here! DAG'S POV - The snowglobe lowers to reveal a real sky ful FLUTTERING WHITE FLAKES. No, not flakes -- pieces of mail drifting to earth. Dag and Penny stare in wonder. ON THE POSTCARDS as they land -- Fairy-tale views of a Manhattan-style city. Dag reads the printed messages.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Live the night life...” “Join us after dark...” “The city that never sleeps!” Dag looks to Penny, amazed -- here’s their answer! Penny' eyes sparkle. They're just_about to kiss again when... THWUMP! MUSIC stops abruptly as Dag and Penny are startle apart by the crash-landing of a PIGEON right in front of them. The pigeon (HOMER ) wears a messenger vest, a mailb slung over one wing, ermos on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Hey lovebirds, sorry to interrupt, it’s just my bag spilled and... spots the snowglobe) Whoa, lucky that didn’t break.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (points to his head) No, but this did.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Sorry dude, nothing serious, right? (holds up his wings) How many wings?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Duh -- two?

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Excellent, no concussion, hey, accidents happen, you got insurance, right? As he talks a mile a minute, he unslings a thermos from h shoulder and pours a cup of coffee. Like many delivery workers, Homer is hypercaffeinated.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell ya what, let’s be cool and not even involve the vultures, dig? And you can keep the doohickey. Dag rubs his head angrily... Penny eyes the snowglobe longingly... Dag eyes Penny longingly...

dialogues.speaker: HOMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... we cool? (off Dag’s shrug) Excellent. I’m Homer.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (as they shake wings) Dagnabbit Shuddup.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Whoa ace, say what now?

dialogues.speaker: ENNY
dialogues.text: That’s his name, call him Dag, I’m Penny.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Thanks, Pen, you are one knockout chick, and one righteous rooster. What are you two doing up this time of night besides, you know, chicken-necking? You two got some nightbird in ya?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: So they say.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: It’s not a bad thing. He picks up scattered postcards. Dag and Penny help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer, where did these come from?

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: The City. You never been to the City?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Is it really a “city that never sleeps?”

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Brother and how. You gotta go, it’1l blow your birdy brains. The Central Park Poopery... The Statue of Lavatory... The International Airport-a-potty! (off their looks) Hey, I’ma a pigeon, the world is my tollet. best of all... (finds a postcard) Birdland! ON POSTCARD - a view of the lavish treetop nightclub.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Home of the famous Treetop Lounge where the nightbirds sing til dawn and closing time's not til tomorrow.” Get off your tailfeathers, check it out! It’s not even that far, you can see it from here! He flutters to the roof of the farmhouse porch. Penny and Dag look helplessly at each other. Then... Dag flaps onto the roof of the henhouse... then onto a ta stack of crates. Penny follows tentatively. Dag leaps to the trellis by the porch, grabs the slats with his claws. reaches his wings out for enny -- and catches her as she jumps. Together they climb up the trellis to join Homer.. ON THE PORCH ROOF - Homer points to the distant lights of glittering skyline. Dag and Penny squint to make it out.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Wow! You think we could make it there?

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Well if you can make it there, you’ll make it anywhere. (sees Penny’s reluctance) You know, you could go first -- get a job, finda place --_and come back for enny once you" re all set up. I’11 help, just _call when ya get there. I’m at the Hotel Broadwa Catch you on the flipside, fow. $! With a salute he takes off. Dag and Penny wave goodbye -- then look at the city. MUSIC UNDER ("If I Could Fly”).

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It's so big... and so distant...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: But it's not non-existent! Now our destination's in sight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a couple of loonies, Out here in the boonies... Still we feel that it's real And it's right! So_ you and I Will keep our eyes on That far horizon Across the sky, Where we'd be free... If only we Could fly. They nestle closer, silhouetted against the moonlit sky. night itself starts to fly via TIME-LAPSE FAST-MOTION: The moon arcs downward -- they draw closer -- Dag puts a around Penny -- she draws away -- they look at the sky -- awkwardly inch together again -- Penny lays her head on Dag’s shoulder -- and he puts his wing around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As sunlight seeps into the sky and paints it in pastels, and Penny nestle together, dozing.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Dag? Isn't it time for you to...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Mmm? Oh yeah, okay... He tries to straighten up and crow... then realizes -- he on the edge of the roof! Groggy, he instantly falls off. Penny SQUAWKS -- then takes a brave, running leap to the crates... down to the henhouse... to the ground. The Farmer emerges from the house, passes unconscious Dag

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Pathetic. He moves to open the gate for a TURNIP TRUCK as it turns As Penny runs to Dag’s side, the other Hens emerge from t henhouse, blinking and stretching in the dawn light. They stare at Penny as if she were a fallen chicken.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HEN
dialogues.text: Pathetic. As the Farmer helps the TRUCK DRIVER load baskets of turn onto his truck, he sees... A LONG BLACK CAR approaching. It noses through the gate a SQUEALS to a stop by the Farmer. Tinted glass rolls down, replacing the Farmer’s reflection with the crabbed face o CAP'N PLUCKETT - a withered despot in a white linen suit. beady-eyed PARROT (PAULIE CRACKERS) rides on his shoulder big RHODE ISLAND RED rooster (RED) dozes at his side; a glowering HOUND DOG (GENERAL LEE) sits at his feet.  10. CAP‘N PLUCKETT Anything to sell me today, Farmer Farmer? The farmer’s shadow closes in on sleeping Dag... who awak rudely as the Farmer hoists him into the air.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: How ‘bout this worthless rooster? Up all night, sleeps all day. Heck, forget selling, I’1ll give him to you. CAP‘N PLUCKETT I do have a certain interest in birds of a nocturnal nature... He pats his own sleeping rooster. The Farmer holds Dag up the window... where he attracts the attention of General The Dog GROWLS. Dag squirms. CAP'N PLUCKETT (CONT’D) But that’s not what I want to purchase.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: I keep telling you, this land’s not for sale. We ain’t dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAP'N PLUCKETT
dialogues.text: Sure you are, you just ain’t got the good sense to lie down. As the sun rises, a LARGE SHADOW FALLS over both men. REV the pastoral farm is bordered by a TOWERING BRICK WALL. A billboard at the top reads “CAP'N PLUCKETT’S POULTRY” - and features a likeness of the old Cap’n himself, lifting drumstick to his mouth with a motorized hand. Up and down goes, as the Cap’n takes the same bite forever. BACK TO SCENE: The Cap’n hands the Farmer an official- looking envelope -- NOTICE OF FORECLOSURE AND EVICTION.

dialogues.speaker: CAP'N PLUCKETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about this, Farmer Farmer. Just doin’ my duty is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doin’ my duty, rawk! Doin’ my duty. Now General Lee BARKS at Dag -- who kicks out and lands a swipe across the dog’s nose. Furious General Lee lunges through the window. The Farmer pulls back and drops Dag.. who runs for his life, with General Lee in hot pursuit. EXT. FARMYARD — DAWN Dag races beneath HOES and RAKES leaning against the wall knocking them over as he passes. Hot on Dag’s tail, the General stumbles and rolls over the clattering tools. He finally rights himself -- and steps right on the blade of hoe which obeys the laws of slapstick and swings upright, CONKING the dog in the noggin. With a flutter of wings, Dag leaps lightly over a haystac Behind him, General Lee plows straight through -- and tum out the other side, spitting hay and pawing it from his e  11. Dag heads straight for the gieeping MULE... and runs unde him, tickling the Mule’s belly as he goes. The Mule jagie in his sleep... then wakes abruptly, annoyed. Who woke hi up? He looks behind him to see... General Lee approaching The Dog sees the angry mule ahead, ready to kick. He trie to brake, but too late... Dag looks back as the mule BRAYS and the bog YELPS. His e follow General Lee’s brief flight and hard landing. THUD. As the Cow and Pig wake, complaining loudly, Dag races to THE HENHOUSE - He dives through the small door with Gener Lee inches behind. WHAM! The dog’s nose wedges tightly in the henhouse door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaking from the impact. Feathers flying. Hens SQUAWKING alarm. Dag hurries to Penny...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Pen, remember we talked about me leaving? Penny nods. Dag points at the dog’s snout behind him, snarling and slavering as it tries to free itself.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seems like a good time. Dag takes a peck at the snout. General Lee YOWLS and strains to pull free of the door. Dag pecks as he talks..

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: It'll be okay, I'll find a job, and I‘1l find a place for us to live....

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Together?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (takes her hint) And I'1l find an all-night wedding chapel!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Dag, are you...?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Sure, will you...? Before Penny can answer... CRRRRRAAAACK! Wood splits as t dog pulls free, with the doorframe still jammed on his sn

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gotta go. As he leaps out the wide-open door...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes! The answer is yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Lee’s at the base of the henhouse ramp, trying to pull the door-frame off his snout...  12. -as Dag leaps out and lands hard on the top of the ramp. The whole thing see-saws -- Dag’s end drops to the ground the other end lands an uppercut to General Lee’s jaw. The dog YOWLS. Dag skeddadles. He takes a running, flappi leap... and barely makes it to the top of the fence. Whew Angry hens watch Dag’s escape from their shattered doorwa

dialogues.speaker: OLD HEN
dialogues.text: Good riddance. EXT. FARMYARD -— CONTINUOUS Dag races along the rail with General Lee running below, snarling jaws open to reveal a mouth full of teeth and dr The Turnip Truck is pulling out of the gate as Dag runs d the fence... and leaps off! He lands on turnips, which roll out from under him. Dag slips -- slides -- almost tumbles off. But he curls his claws around a truckbed rail and hangs on for dear life a General Lee gallops through the gate, keeping pace. The d launches himself into the air, lunging at the tailgate... Dag cringes as the dog torpedoes at him... then drops. DU illows as Lee hits the ground. Missed it by that much. J settles his tailfeathers into the truckload of turnips, watching the farm and furious General Lee shrink away.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so our hero made the epic journe from rural heartland to sin-soaked city. A jazzy version of “(Get Your Kicks on) Route 66” plays a

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: DAG’‘S ROAD-TRIP MONTAGE - Bucolic heartland pastures pas as a SUPERIMPOSED ROAD MAP charts the truck’s progress wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dotted line... Rural road signs become highway markers: R 66, US 10 Forests and lakefronts give way to suburban sprawl as... that DOTTED LINE nears a BIG CITY on the map

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: He’s a little fuzzy on the details, since he was traveling by day... ON THE TRUCK BED -- where Dag dozes on turnips, SNORING.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: -so he pretty much slept through the whole trip. PULL BACK TO REVEAL the truck is now crawling in four lan of heavy traffic on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until the truck is just one of a thousand colorful specks crossing the water into the BIG CITY SKYLINE.  13. EXT. FARMER'S MARKET -— AFTERNOON ON DAG - jolted awake as the truck stops. His eyes open.. DAG'S POV - CITY SKYSCRAPERS soar into the sky. Dag blinks, looks again. The SKYSCRAPERS grow even taller Suddenly the truck RATTLES as the driver opens the tailga to unload. Dag SQUAWKS and leaps onto the street... Where he’s nearly CREAMED by CAR TIRES speeding past. He retreats under the truck... And emerges on the other side. Sighs with relief -- then SQUAWKS as he’s nearly trampled by sidewalk PEDESTRIANS. scurries one way to avoid RUSHING FEET -- then jumps the other way as a BICYCLE whizzes by. He dives for safety..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag crouches by a TRASHCAN, breathing hard as he gapes at the people and traffic barrelling past. He doesn’t see th HEAD rising out of the trash above him -- black mask arou beady eyes -- meet COONEY the raccoon.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: Well well well, what we have we here, Poss? -.-Poss? Next to him in the trashcan dozes a POSSUM -- his partner crime POSS, the smaller and, at this hour, sleepier of th pair. Their partnership is a Penn—and-Teller affair, with Cooney doing all the talking.) Cooney nudges Poss awake.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think this boy’s new in town? (calls down to Dag) Need some help, son? Dag looks around --where’s that voice coming from? He’s startled as Cooney leaps from the can and lands beside hi

dialogues.speaker: COONEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet your mama told you not to talk to strangers, so let’s be strangers no more. I’m Cooney, and this is my partner, Poss. Poss lands on the other side, again catching Dag off-guar

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Hey! Hi... I’m Dag. (off Poss’s mute reaction) Doesn’t talk much, does he?

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: Silent partner.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Could you tell me how to get to Birdland? Cooney and Poss trade a look -- can’t resist the set-up.  14.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: Practice! Practice! (laughs, then) I could tell you were a musician.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: You could? I am? See, it’s my first time in the city...

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: No kiddin’. Fresh off the farm, no experience, you’ll get yourself in big trouble without expert professionals to steer your career. Lucky you found us. He nudges Poss, who hands Dag a business card. Dag reads:

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: “Cooney & Poss, Scavenging and Hauling?” Cooney snatches the card away, as Poss hands Dag another.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Cooney & Poss, Pest Control!” Cooney grabs Poss’s handful of business cards, fans throu them til he finds the one he wants. Hands it to Dag... DAG (CONT’D) “Cooney & Poss, Artists Management.” Shoot, I’m no artist.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: We'll be the judge of that. Show us what you got -- sing, dance, whatever you do.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Oh, I just crow a little... Cooney and Poss feign eagerness. Bashful, Dag clears his throat... SQUEAKS... settles... and starts to CROW.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brakakaw, brakakaw, brakakeeeee... baby! Brakakaw brakakaw... ON A WINDOW LEDGE high above, Mack the mockingbird is adjusting his tie in the window’s reflection, singing:

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Listen to the mockingbird, oh that crazy mockingbird... He stops as he hears Dag crowing below. Bops to the beat hey, not bad. He looks for the source of the sound... BACK TO SCENE -- as Dag finishes big.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Brakak, brakeek, babop-dop-deep dra-kow!

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: Whoa, dig that crazy sound. You got a lotta talent. But not a lotta know-how, nachaur Van naad a anand mananar  15. Cooney starts to rub Dag’s shoulders with his paws... As he talks, Cooney siyly lifts a corner of Dag’s left wi Poss reaches underneat! poking around for a pocket to pic

dialogues.speaker: COONEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’ll make sure ya meet the right birds. Get the best gigs... Poss shakes his head, nothing. So Cooney lifts the right wing while Poss pokes. -

dialogues.speaker: COONEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And above_all, make sure nobody exploits you. Really, "thirty percent’s a small price to pay.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Thirty percent of what?... Hey! Dag’s caught Poss in the act. Cooney scrambles to cover..

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: He's pest checking your measurements, you'll need some new outfits. First we jet you a stylist, some good pictures, I now some guys, I’ll get you a deal. Then we'll get you a personal trainer... (off Dag’s reaction) You’re no spring chicken, bubbe, those drumsticks need definition. All at minimal cost, a small investment in your future, how much money do you have, anyway, and where do you keep it? Actually, r aeinda left home in a hurry today. I didn’t bring any cash. Cooney and Poss trade looks -- and change moods. Cooney flexes his claws, grabs Dag by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: Listen, 2°, rube, this is the City, you wanna make it here, it costs money. Now are you gonna help us help you? Or do we have to shake it outta you? Cooney shoves frightened Dag against a wall. Then... the raccoon’s expression changes from menace to pain.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yow! REVEAL mockingbird Mack has landed squarely on Cooney’s h grabbing a furry ear in each claw.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: geagney) You dirty overgrown furry rat -- let him go, or the ears come off. (digs in; Pacino/Scarface) I‘ll rip em off and shove em up your nose, say goo’bye to your leetle yeriends!  16.

dialogues.speaker: COONEY
dialogues.text: Yaaaaaaa, get off me! He releases Dag. Scared Poss or dies onto his back, playi ossum. As Cooney escapes grabs Poss’s tail and drags im along, racing out o the al ey. Mack looks Dag over...

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: New in town, kid?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: How’dja know?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Lucky guess. Just fell off the turnip truck, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: No! ...I jumped off.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Yeah? What’s your name, kid?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Dagnabbit Shuddup.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hey, shuddup yourself, I was just asking!

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: That's my name, Dagnabbit_Shuddup. That’s what the farmer calls me, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hunh. How’s about I call you Dag? (extends a wing) | Mack the Mock, stand-up comic and stand- up bird, at your service.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Wow. You’re in show biz?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me -- just where you wanna be.

dialogues.speaker: AG
dialogues.text: I never really thought about it til Mr. Cooney said..

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Yeah well, forget anything that con- artist tells ya.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I suspected he wasn’t quite on the level.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: What tipped you off? The burglar’s mask? The prison-stripes? Or when he tried to mug ya? Listen, kid, this town’s full of guys like Cooney, happy to take all the lough while you do a the work. You got a sweet souni kid, but you need some street-— smarts, stat. You got a job yet? Maybe I can help. Follow me!  17. He spreads his wings and takes off. Dag watches him go. After a beat... Mack returns.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What ’samatter?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Can't fly.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, roosters, right, I knew that. Okay, I’1l go slow so you can keep up. Hey, you know how to get to Birdland?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: «..Practice?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Heard that one, hunh? Come on... As Mack takes off, Dag double-takes...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Birdland? We’re going to Birdland? And he races out of the alley...

dialogues.speaker: TWILIGHT
dialogues.text: DAG’'S POV - A HUNDRED PAIRS OF LEGS, towering above and clomping past him as he navigates the city sidewalk. Dag escapes the crunch to hug a wall -- scans the sky... Perched on a streetlight, Mack waves at Dag, flies on. DAG dodges an oncoming CYCLIST -- lands in the path of a SKATEBOARDER, who swerves in the nick of time. DAG spins the skateboard whizzes by... to find himself face-to-face with... a PACK OF SLOBBERING, GROWLING DOGS.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Brakkkk! He turns and runs. The Dogs YAP and charge after him. Luckily they’re on all leashes held by a hapless DOGWALKE

dialogues.speaker: DOGWALKER
dialogues.text: Heel! Heel! HEEL! From a telephone wire, Mack sees the Dogwalker dragged by dogs as Dag makes his escape.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hey Dag! Grab a cab! Dag spreads his wings and takes a flying leap onto the a parked car -- and from there a passing YELLOW CAB. SPLAT! From the CABBIE’S POV -- as Dag lands and immediat gets flattened across the windshield, wings oustretched.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Move ya stupid bird...  18. Dag tries to smile at the Cabbie -- until the WINDSHIELD WIPERS start up, whipping him back and forth across the windshield. He scrambles to climb up to... THE ROOF OF THE CAB -- where he almost tumbles off -- but curls his claws around the “TAXI” signs and hangs on. MACK'S POV - Dag perches atop the cab, riding through hea traffic up a street that looks a lot like Broadway. As th cab stops at a light, we swoop down, circling above Dag..

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Take a right! Dag eyes the crossing traffic, takes a running leap into TRUCK. Going in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your other right! This way! Dog reconnoiters, jumps onto a car headed the other way, his claws into the canvas top. He searches the sky for Ma

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right behind ya. Dag yelps, surprised. Mack has landed on the car top.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We get off at this next... The car hits an_ intersection and SQUEALS to a stop -- se our heroes tumbling off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag and Mack land hard, rolling on the pavement. Luckily they’re stopped. : « WHAM! WHAM! By the trunk of an enorm tree. As they struggle to their feet, Dag looks up to see GOTHIC CATHEDRAL TOWERS (think St. Patrick’s) soaring abo

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: We're going to church?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Quite the contrary. He taps on the massive tree-trunk with his beak. A speake style PEEPHOLE OPENS. Glinting eyes and a GRUFF VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah? Oh, hiya Mack. A DOOR opens in the trunk, revealing the Club Bouncer ins COCKY CACCIATORE, a burly, greying rooster.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Dag, meet Cocky Cacciatore. The Cocky Cacciatore.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Yeah? Wow.  19.

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: He never heard of me.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Sure I have. (off Cocky’s stare) No I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: He was World Cockfighting Champ five years running is al

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: “Was” being the key word. Can’t expect kids to know ancient history. Hiya, Dag. They shake wings. Mack and Dag step inside. Cocky sticks his head out, yells upward

dialogues.speaker: COCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, fellas. PAN UP TO REVEAL four big, burly NIGHTHAWKS perched on branches above -- each harnessed to a rope that passes in the tree and down to the elevator. The Hawks flap and tak off in four directions... pulling the elevator up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it rises, Cocky studies Dag.

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: Kinda past your bedtime, ain’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Think we got a nightbird here, like you.

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Happy to welcome another freak of nature. You come to the right place kid. MUSIC begins as the elevator stops. Doors open to reveal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag gapes like Dorothy in Oz as he enters Birdland, even spectacular than its postcard. On the gargoyle- framed st a_chorus line of NIGHTINGALES rehearse as the Crow Bar ba plays and a fey jaybird (BUSBY BIRDLY) directs.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTINGALES
dialogues.text: Nightbirds! You came to the right birds, This place will ignite, birds, When we get hot! And we get hot a lot...

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW
dialogues.text: Callin’ all nightbirds, All you blackbirds and white birds-- Wanna hit a new height, birds? This is the spot! Eying Dag, Busby sings along with the chorus...  20.

dialogues.speaker: BUSBY
dialogues.text: You feeling blue, bird? Lost all your spark? Cheer _up, boy, and come enjoy Some laughter after dark! Mack smiles fondly as he mutters to Dag:

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: He’s a screaming jaybird, but he puts on a helluva show. Dag is in jazz heaven, chicken-dancing along to the band.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Man, they’re great! I can’t wait to play with them.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hunh? Aw, no, kid, you’re not workin with the band, you’re gonna be a busbird.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (trying to hide disappointment ) Oh! Well that’s good too. I mean, I’1l still be kinda showbiz... adjacent.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: DAG - now wearing a red busbird’s jacket, as Mack finishe tying Dag’s bowtie. REVEAL we're in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag stands at the end of a line of Waiters and Busbirds a the NIGHTHAWK MAITRE D’ inspects his staff, singing: MAITRE D’ Another busy night, birds! So don't get uptight, birds -- No fights and no flight, birds -- Stay on your toes! The Waiters do a quick tap-break, twirling their trays. D joins in clumsily, following their lead. MAITRE D’ (CONT'D) The customer's always right, birds! So keep it polite, birds, And see that tonight, birds, Everything flows! The Waiters perform a balletic routine, assing their tray down the line... to Dag, who ends up holding the whole st

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: DAG - LATER - navigating with his tray through a PACKED H -- drunken LOONS, cuddling LOVEBIRDS, GULLS in sailor hat and macho NIGHTHAWKS chirping up NIGHTINGALES and DOVES. Club's open, and it’s hopping. As Dag clears plates...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Who knew there were so many... Nightbirds?  21. DAG (CONT'D . there pi § just. a-light-bite birds... s up big bowls) And £5 appetite birds! He checks out the ENORMOUS PIGEON who polished off the bo

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He gives new meaning to eat-like-a-bird. He moves to another table, where dandified, drunken LOONS laugh as they drop empties on his tray.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see high-as-a-kite birds... Moving to another table, where a party of HUMMINGBIRDS li across the tabletop, claws up, deeply asleep.

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And out-like-a-light birds... spoken) can't old their nectar. (grins, , sings) And all of ‘em nightbirds, Just like me! ON THE STAGE - as the Chorusbirds sing:

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTINGALES
dialogues.text: It's time to stay. up late, birds -- So bring a hot date, birds, Or hunt for a mate, birds, Right here and now! ON MACK - now cuddling up to a matronly OWL in the front

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hey, I found her! Wow!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTINGALES
dialogues.text: No reason to wait, birds, So don't hesitate, birds -- There's gaggles of great birds Right here, and how! Mack joins Artie and the band for a splashy finale, as th chorusbirds do a G-rated “fan dance” with peacock feather

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Yeah, only the preferred land Here -- in -- Birdland! They bring their fans together... then cascade them apart reveal a REAL PEACOCK, taller than anyone else on stage, spreads his regal tail as a dazzling backdrop for the fin

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY
dialogues.text: Come fly with the -- Nightbirds! Here we're allowed to be nightbirds! ON DAG, in back, wowed by the show and singing softly alo

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: And we're proud to be niahtbirds!  22.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: What a crowd! Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY
dialogues.text: Nightbirds are the right birds to be! The crowd WHISTLES, CROWS and CLAPS THEIR WINGS as the curtain falls as Mack takes the mic:

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Thanks everybody we're gonna take a little brea! but stick to your perches, we got two more shows!

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: DAG - still dreamy-eyed as Mack approaches... MACK (CONT’D So ya like the show, kid? Stupid peacock keeps missing his cue, there’s a guy got hired for his looks. Suddenly Mack stiffens at the sight of Paulie Crackers an Red -- the parrot and rooster we saw with Cap’ n Pluckett Mack and Paulie glare, feathers ruffling. ey know each other. And don’t like what they know.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, look what the cat dragged in.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (“hello Jerry”) Hello... Mack.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: ("hello Newman” ) Hello... Paulie. Dag, Paulie Crackers. He used to be in showbiz, but he couldn’t make it. There’s just one Bird of a Thousand Voices. He’s only got twelve.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Joe Pesci) I didn’t like showbiz. Because I am not a clown. Do I look like a clown to you?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Honest answer?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Showbiz is for clowns. I’m managing fighters now. Like the champ here.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Good for you. Come on, Dag, time to meet the boss. As he pulls Dag away, Mack points upwards -- through the leafy canopy -- to the church tower soaring into the nigh

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Dag, this is Mister “Bats” Amore.  23.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (gasping for breath) It’s... a... pleasure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “BATS” AMORE -- yes, he’s a bat, in formalwear -- drops f the rafter he’s hanging from, flips upright to look Dag o

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: He had to take the stairs. Roosters, they can’t fly, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. And another thing the can’t do? They can’t stay awake! The last one slept all night.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: This kid’s a nightbird like Cocky. He’s a real dynamo... normally.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (still panting) You gotta... lotta... stairs.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Johnny! Get him some water. JOHNNY GUANO, a brawny, brainless bat, fills a glass from rainspout -- and SPLASHES it in Dag’s face. BATS AMORE (CONT’D) To drink, you idiot.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: That’s okay... felt good.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: My associate, Johnny Guano. And you are?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Dagnabbit Shuddup.

dialogues.speaker: BATS
dialogues.text: .-Dagnabbit, what did you say to me?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: (hastens to intervene) His name is Shuddup, long story, Mr. A, with which we will not bore you, call him Dag. Give him a try-out, hunh?

dialogues.speaker: BATS
dialogues.text: Show me what you got tonight. Then we'll talk turkey.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hey, that’s good boss. Talkin’ turkey to a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: BATS
dialogues.text: You know about “three strikes you're out?” Here you only get one. Johnny -- give the kid a ride down.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny glides down on outstretched wings past winding sta holding nervous Dag in his claws. As they hit bottom...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Watch your step Rooster. (then, guffaws) Get it? Your “step,” ‘cuz you can’t...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: ‘Cuz I can’t fly, yessir, funny. With a WHOOSH of wings, Johnny circles back up to the sha as Mack flies down, lands by Dag.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hey, be careful with these guys. You know why they call Mr. Amore, “Bats?”

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: -..’cuz he’s a bat?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Because he’s bat-poop insane. So from now on? Let me do the talking. You just keep your eyes open and your beak shut. Dag nods eagerly -- eyes wide open, beak tightly shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SNACK BIRD passes with a trayful of STIFFENED WORMS, hawking her wares like a cigarette girl in a human club.

dialogues.speaker: SNACK BIRD
dialogues.text: Centipedes... millipedes... worms... centipedes... millipedes... worms...

dialogues.speaker: BATS
dialogues.text: Over here, sweetheart. Bats and Johnny now occupy a_ leafy booth overlooking the club. Bats plucks a big millipede from the Snack Bird’s t -- bites off the head and spits it out like a cigar tip - and starts nibbling. He flips a coin onto the tray. ANOTHER PART OF THE CLUB - Dag maneuvers through the crow with a full tray. He hears a FANFARE, looks to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: My friends, get ready for a trip to the moon on the gossamer wings and the silken voice of Miss -- Flo -- Nightingale! The curtain parts to reveal FLO NIGHTINGALE in all her glittery glory. Packed into sequins, she’s one hot chick. The band plays an INTRO, she opens her beak to sing, and. CRASH! The band stops. Flora stops. ALL EYES turn to... Dumbfounded Dag, who has dropped his tray.  25. Everyone reacts -- CUSTOMERS laugh and hoot... Bats and Johnny narrow their beady eyes... Flo stares... then smil

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Now that’s what I call a reaction. (crowd laughter) One more time, boys. (to Dag) And honey? Easy on the percussion. Dag stares at the stage, goofy-beaked and dreamy-eyed. The Band strikes up the fanfare again. Flo sings: “NEVER TRY TO CLIP MY WINGS”

dialogues.speaker: FLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shy? Me? (sultry laugh) Try me. But once we're done, let's turn the page-- When our time's flown by, Then I gotta fly... ‘Cause this bird don't sing in a cage! You can date me, You can hate me, Just don't incarcerate me. Keep adorin' me Tilt you're borin’ me, Just never lock the door on me. You can woo me, Pursue me, Do ooh, so many things, But never try to clip my wings. Flo slithers offstage into the front row, where she sings admiring nightbirds -- a tipsy Loon, a tough-guy Nighthaw

dialogues.speaker: FLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘ma lover, not a fighter, ‘ma kisser, not a biter, ‘m a lovebird just as long I'm free! Hold me Lightly, not too tightly -- Maybe every other nightly? And onew me how ya Tove to fight for me! oken) Take (Spe Artie...

dialogues.speaker: BAHN
dialogues.text: THE BAND swings into its musical break. As Artie starts wailing his clarinet solo... DAG starts to bop with the music. With the full tray held his wings, he shuts his eyes, sways, steps, spins... and bumps b indly into the SNACK CHICK, who tumbles into a ta of drunken LOONS -- who laugh as worms fly everywhere. Mack rolls his eyes, hurries to control Dag... Too late. As the music soars, Dag’s throat puffs... his wattle wobbles... and he lets loose his own jazzy CROW.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Ek-ek-ek-ek-ek-arooooo! Possessed by the music, he hurls his tray into the air...  26. Mack races to catch the tray -- then uses it to catch the glasses tumbling through the air. Artie BLASTS his clarinet to drown Dag out... but Dag jus blasts right back: DAG (CONT’D) Erkaroo-erkaroo-erkarooo-ak! Mack catches a bowl on his head -- and misses the last gl which CRASHES to the floor. The MUSIC STOPS. Artie has stopped playing to stare at Da Bats and Johnny are staring, too. So are all the customer Dag’s oblivious as he blissfully CROWS. Eyes closed, he doesn’t notice Mack tugging his wing. So Mack sticks his beak straight into Dag’s ear...

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Dagnabbit Shuddup! Dag’s eyes open. His beak closes. Sees everyone staring..

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW
dialogues.text: May we continue? A-one-two-three and... The MUSIC cranks up as Johnny approaches angrily.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: What can I say, the kid likes music.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: Yeah? He screws up again, you’re both gonna be hearing angel music. Mack looks to see if Dag gets the message... but the rooster’s staring dreamily at the stage as... Flo returns to the mic. She winks at Dag as she sings:

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: You can kiss me, Or diss me, Or buy me diamond rings, But never try to clip my wings! (big finish) You can grip me, Unzip me, And don't be reluctant to tip me! But never -- ever -- clip My wings. The crowd goes wild. Flo takes her bows... Mack corners Dag, beak-to-beak.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: What’d I tell ya? Eyes open, beak shut. And what do you do? Shut your eyes and open your stupid beak! I oughta...  27.

dialogues.speaker: RED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey baby, I‘’1l1 unzip ya! Mack and Dag look to see... Red, the hulking | rooster who came in with Paulie, now l drunkenly from his ringside seat to the stage...

dialogues.speaker: RED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1ll unzip ya and tip ya, how about that?

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Okay, hon, I wasn’t singing just to you. Flo tries to exit gracefully, but the Rooster grabs her. ON MACK - seething.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: I’‘1ll handle this, Dag. Dag? Dag’s already gone. Mack reacts to SQUEALS and CRASHES... --.as Dag leaps from one table to another, charging strai for the STAGE. Red barely has time to react...

dialogues.speaker: ROOSTER
dialogues.text: What the...? ...-before Dag barrels into him. Feathers fly and the roosters roll straight into the bandstand. Artie and the crows SQUAWK and take flight as Dag and Red smash into th drum set. Dag’s head plunges through the bass drum. Red sits Up fast-- and CLANGS his head against the cymbals. P Dag pulls his head out of the drum. ROOSTER (CONT’D) Hey! You know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Yeah you’re the guy who was just leaving. Dag grabs Red by his wings -- hoists him to his feet-- an hurls him off the stage onto a table. Food and drinks go flying. So do the Loons who were sitting there. The table at the end of a branch -- it bounces as Red lands. Dag jumps from the stage to the table -- bending the bran down further. As he lands briefly... DAG (CONT’D) And stay out! Dag jumps off. The branch snaps back up, catapulting Red into the air. Everyone in the club watches Red rise up, u up... CRUNCH. Red SLAMS against an overhanging buttress. Everyo watches him tumble down, down to the street below. Mack smiles at Paulie..

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: So much for your chump, sorry, champ.  28. Paulie fixes Mack with a beady, malevolent guare. - then spreads his wings and dives to help his fallen champion. CAMERA-LENS POV - LONG SHOT of the chaos in the club. The CAMERA IRIS ADJUSTS and ZOOMS IN ON DAG... REVERSE SHOT - of a hole in the trunk of the Birdland tre high above the club floor -- the penthouse. TWO ORANGE EY GLOW within the darkness, irises tightening to focus on D BACK TO SCENE: Artie and the crows put the bandstand back together. Flo and Mack support Dag as Bats and Johnny approach.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Okay, that’s it, you’re outta here.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: They were just trying to help. Which is more than some bats I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Mind your Manners, you're talking to a mamma’

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I didn’t see any mighty mammals racing to my rescue. (to Dag) Thanks, honey, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Not for long he’s not. (moving in on Dag) That guy you just bounced...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: “Bounced,” that’s good, boss...

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Do you know who he was?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: No sir, funny, he asked me the same thing, not even he knows who he is.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: He’s Ready Red O’Reilly, the Rhode Island Redneck, the world bantamweight cock- fighting champ, that’s who!

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I couldn’t have. (delayed reaction) | The world-which what-fight who now?

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Too complicated for you? How’s this? You're fired. Heave-ho. Dag is devastated. Flo and Mack hold their beaks as Johnn grabs Dag and spreads his wings to carry him out.  29.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Heave whoooocc-hooo? Everyone’s startled by the appearance of... DON OWLEONE - owner of the bright orange eyes, an old, Brandoesque owl, soft-spoken and hard-nosed.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: No heave-ho without my say-so. (stares at Dag) Tell me, my cocky young hothead, just whoo-hoo do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Dagnabbit Shud...

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: (intervenes ) His name is Dag, sir, Dagy meet Don Owleone. A-K-A the God-feather. MUSIC UNDER - as Artie and the Crows play a plaintive Ita ballad to underscore the Don’s scene.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: That was a very gutsy display, Dag, knocking out the bantamweight champ. You’re an impressive young hooooligan.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Oh I just got lucky, sir. Most roosters get pretty dopey this time of night.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: But not you. You’re a natural nightbird, aren’tcha? Roohoosters like you are rare. Have you ever fought professionally?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Gockfighting? Me? Oh, no, sir. I’m just... well, like Miss Flo sings, “I’ma over, not a fighter.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Flo, hmm?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If the Don wants you to fight, you’l1l fight.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Who-hoo asked you? You heard the bird. Can't make him fly against his nature.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Especially when he can’t fly.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: I like you, rooster. Tell me, can I help you in any way?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I’m just happy to be here, sir. Of course, I'd love to work with the band.  30.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: I’‘1ll_ talk to Artie. And perhaps one day I will ask a favor in return. As the old owl turns from Dag, he murmurs to Bats...

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s more than one way to pluck a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vertical neon sign blinks “HOTEL”. In the channel betwe the sides, nest-boxes rise up like Japanese hotel-cubicle In the lowest “room,” our friend Homer is waking up. He waddles to the open front of his cubicle -- turns Fis tailfeathers to us, squats over the edge. As we PAN UP aw from the pigeon going potty, we hear...

dialogues.speaker: PEDESTRIAN BELOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! Yuck. We RISE PAST other RESIDENTS -- pigeons waking up -- nightingale gargling on her way to bed -- two Lovebirds cuddling and cooing -- and finally, at the top... DAG lies in his cubicle, listening. The morning birds CHI Sirens BLARE. TRAFFIC builds. He stares over the waking city, toward the farm he left behind. Garish neon flashes across his face. Alone for the first time, Dag looks scar He pulls a POSTCARD from beneath his pillow, starts writi

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dear Penny -- well, I got work! At Birdland! It’s beén some ni ht, but Penny, you’re gonna love it eré...

dialogues.speaker: THE SAME SCENE, UPSIDE DOWN
dialogues.text: REVEAL JOHNNY GUANO hanging from a nearby tree branch, watching Da He squints in the rising sunlight, pulis sunglasses rom beneath his wing and puts them on. JOHNNY’S POV - of Dag, now shaded in night-vision green. INT. DAG’S ROOM- MOMENTS LATER Homer takes Dag’s postcard, puts it in his bag.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l get it to her pronto. And make sure she gets to you.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Thanks, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Dude, we're all in the same flock, right? He spreads his wings and takes off.  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer soars above the skyscrapers...

dialogues.speaker: DAG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The city’s like nothing you ever saw. I can’t wait for you to get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer flies above a pastoral landscape. He squints, puzzl HOMER'S POV - Dag’s farm is now surrounded by BARBED-WIRE FENCING. Signs warn: KEEP OUT... UNDER CONSTRUCTION... PLUCKETT’S POULTRY IS EXPANDING! Flying lower, Homer sees The Farmer and his Wife load furniture and boxes loaded o their rickety truck... while Pluckett watches from his bi car, smiling as two of his MEN load cages onto another tr Homer heads in for a landing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cages on the truck are full of HENS... including Penn

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Homer? Homer!

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Hey Penny -- special delivery. He passes postcard through the bars. She passes one back.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thank goodness, can you get this to Dag? They lost the farm! They're leaving. And they’re leaving us... to him. She gestures up to the billboard above, where the giant C endlessly chews his giant drumstick.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: No! We gotta get you outta here! Homer starts to peck at the cage latch. Then... BLAM! He YELPS and flaps wildly as a bullet just misses him. PLUCKETT’S MAN Scat, ya dang air-rat! The Man holds a SMOKING RIFLE. He shoots again... BLAM! Homer leaps into the air as the bullet whizzes beneath hi With Pluckett’s other Man in the driver’s seat, the truck REVS to life and starts to move. Homer flaps above... HOMER. Don’t worry, I’ll get Dag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yow! We’ll get you out! BLAM! Homer soars skyward... as the gunman climbs aboard truck... and the truck heads out the gate.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hurey Unmartl wnrrvt  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer lands atop the sign, hops into Dag’s cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Dag? Hey, Dag... He notices a leathery black blanket spread over Dag’s nes

dialogues.speaker: HOMER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Love what you’ve done with the place, sort of a cowboy goth vibe. Dag? He doesn’t see the “bedspread” start to enfold him -- as Johnny Guano sits up, wrapping his wings around Homer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: He ain’t here. Got called to work early. Where ya been, pigeon? He grins -- exposing those shiny fangs. Homer gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crow Bar Band members are gathering, swilling coffee warming up on their instruments, as Dag approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW
dialogues.text: Well if it isn’t Mister Steal the Show. Meet the other crows, that’s Russell on drums-- Cheryl on keyboards-- and the Old Crow himself on bass. Russell and Cheryl wave. The Old Crow lifts a pint flask toast, swigs some down.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The management tells me you're working for us. But let’s get clear here, you’re at the bottom of the pecking order, dig? (illustrates on piano) Here/s me. = h ays hi note then 810°Grows ) (lower notes) Then Cheryl, then Russell... (the lowest note of all) Then you. Got it? (off Dag’s nod) You just_get what we need, sit in on rehearsals and one gay Maybe -- maybe we'll let you jam with us. Gotta work your way up. Ya start out shovelin’ elephant poop -- but then one day -- you’re the elephant. You dig, Dag? (then, gently) I heard you out there, you got a gift. But you gotta learn to give back. You wanna play jazz, you gotta be a team player. Nightbirds look out for each other. So just pay attention, dig? But Dag’s distracted by the arrival of... FLO. Even witho spandex and spangles, she looks good. Maybe better.  33.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +..Dag? You dig?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Hmm? Oh yessir, pay attention, I dig.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Hi, boys, Cheryl! Hey, my hero! Never caught your name.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: §speechisss with infatuation) D-d-duh. D-d-duh..

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW
dialogues.text: Dag, meet Flo, Flo, Dag.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Nice to know ya, Dag.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: My p-p-puh. My p-puh-puh.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Mine too. Thanks for putting that big cock-a-doofus in his place.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, his flat-on-his-face place! He had it coming! I was gonna take him out myself, but you beat me to the punch! Dag basks in good fellowship. Flo pecks him on the cheek. He blushes through his feathers, as the Crows caw raucous

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Aaah, they don’t know squat about how to treat a lady. Chivalry was dead in this dump before you showed up. So thank you, my nightbird in shining feathers. You ever wanna go out after the show some time, I'll elaborate on my gratitude. With a last, devastating wink at dumbstruck Dag, she’s of the dressing rooms. The crows are still cawing...

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE CAW
dialogues.text: Okay, settle down, cats. Dag, you pay attention and work hard, and we'll al make some crazy music together.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Work hard, yessir, I will. (still gazing after Flo) Mister Caw? Could I get tonight off? The Crows grin and caw good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UPSIDE-DOWN SHOT of sweating Homer finishing story.  34.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: -..and I said I’d tell Dag and we'd save her but if she’s headed for Pluckett’s I figure she’s probably plucked already and that’s all I know I Swear please don’t hurt me I got kids to feed! REVEAL this time the bats are upright -- it’s Homer who's upside-down, strung up with the strap of his own mailbag.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: You don’t have any kids.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: ...I know some kids.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Okay, let him go, Johnny. Disappointed, Johnny unstraps Homer who THUDS to the floo Bats reads from the end of Penny’s letter... BATS AMORE (CONT’D) “Dag --_come back! Need your help!” (malevolent inspiration) Hunh. Johnny -- think you can forge this chicken-scratch?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: Sure, boss.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Let’s put a “don’t” here... and one here... and we’ll add a nice P.S. Off Homer, helplessly watching the bats hatch their schem INT. FLO’S DRESSING ROOM As Dag knocks and enters...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Miss Nightingale?

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Dag? Over here. And call me Flo. Dag looks toward a DRESSING SCREEN... just as a dress fli over the top. He gulps.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Oh, I can come back later...

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Relax, honey, I’1l be right out. A slip flips over the screen. Dag tries to stay cool. Next... a bra. Dag’s feathers ruffle. FLO (CONT’D) Didja come to make that date? Flo emerges in a kimono-style robe. Dag exhales loudly.  35.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss -- Flo, believe me, I’d love to, but... I got a girl back home.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: But she’s back home, right? And I’m right here.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: You sure are. But I’m kind of a one-hen rooster. Flo retreats, regards him with a new eye.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Fresh off the farm, aren’tcha? You are adorable.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Thanks, Miss -- Flo. You, too.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dag? You back here? (appears in doorway) Oops, am I interrupting something?

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Sadly, no.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Dag -- we gotta talk. Sounds urgent. Flo watches Dag exit with Homer. BLUESY MUSIC UP: “NEW BIRD IN TOWN.”

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: New bird in town, Dumb as a tourist, Green as the purest cornball corn... New bird in town, Fresh as a farmyard morn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer and Dag perch beneath a gargoyle. Dag looks devasta as he reads Penny’s postcard - Homer avoids his pal’s eye he’s a bad liar and feels awful about deceiving Dag.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: “Don't come back. Don’t need your help. PS - I’ll be safe at Pluckett’s. A nice rooster named Red has taken me under his wing.”

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: Wow, that was fast.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Did you talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: No, well, yeah, I mean, not for long, she just said, um, “Tell Dag I’m sorry.”  36.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. As Dag turns away, Homer almost collapses with the effort lying. Suddenly... Dag leaps off the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: No, don’t, she’s not worth... it. Homer sees Dag has landed on another gargoyle right below

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I just need some alone time. And he hops to a lower gargoyle... then a lower one... on way to the street below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC MONTAGE - As Flo sings “New Bird in Town”, we see D and Penny, lonely and abandoned in their new homes.

dialogues.speaker: FLO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: New bird in town, left on his only, So lost and lonely At every turn... CITY STREETS - DAG waddles past a movie theatre, looks up the POSTER, a wedding scene -- the groom has his arm arou the bride -- and the bride has her arm around the best ma “THREE’S A CROWD!” Dag moves on, nearly gets creamed by.. THUNK -- a pile of tabloid newspapers landing in front of NEWSSTAND. Dag blinks at the headline: “JENNA CATCHES BRE CHEATING!” He hurries on.

dialogues.speaker: FLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: New bird in town, He's got a lot to learn. AT PLUCKETT’S - PENNY’s in her cage as the truck pulls in LOADING DOCK. She looks up at the towering walls of cages rising on every side, like a maximum-security prison. IN THE CITY - DAG avoids PEDESTRIAN FEET as he slogs thro a busy intersection much like Times Square. Above him, brightly-lit billboards blare their ads: For mouthwash -- “Can't Get the Girl? Get Freshex!” (Dag cups a wingtip around his beak, sniffs his breath.) For cologne -- “She’ll Never Tell -- But Maybe You Smell. (Dag lifts a wing, sniffs a pit.) For jewels: “If You Don’t Treat Her Right Someone Else Wi Dag sags, moves on...

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: So far from what you knew So far from love so true, So far from your old ‘hood, And so far, kid, not so good... AT PLUCKETT’S — GRINDING MACHINERY cranks up. Penny ($0 S as Pluckett’s man lifts her cage and hanas it on a ho  37. It swings and sways, tossing Penny back and forth, as it lifts her cage up, up, up to join the other prisoners. IN THE CITY, Dag perches on a railing watching happy hour humans going in and out of a bar. He sees a_ gentle tug-o war, as TWO GUYS argue over who's faking a a GIRL home. T Girl rejects one, heads off with the other The loser stan helplessly as couples swarm around him. Dag blinks away a tear. He knows how the guy feels. Then. THUNDER rumbles -- and rain starts falling. The two lonel hearts, rooster and human, are drenched. AT PLUCKETT’S, Penny’s cage drops with a CLANG into a spa between other cages. She peers through the shadows at her prison-mates -- ragged roosters, hopeless hens, dead chic walking. The huge metal door DROPS -- plunging Penny and prisoners into darkness. MUSIC CARRIES OVER as we

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. DON OWLEONE’S PENTHOUSE - NIGHT A shadowy tree-chamber reminiscent of the Godfather’s glo Tahoe spread. Cockfighting posters and celebrity-bird pho hang on the walls. Owleone sings to Bats, Johnny and Flo.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: New bird in town, Innocent creature... He needs a teacher, Gentle but stern... Flo realizes he means her. She shakes her head, “forget i and backs away... into Bats and Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: BATS / JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Don't let us down, He's got so much to learn.

dialogues.speaker: OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Whooo knows, the city’s nitty- Gritty might start lookin’ pretty... Whooo knows, he may discover He's a fighter, not a lover.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Aw, leave the kid alone. Owleone swiftly wraps a claw around Flo’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me what to do-hoo! Now here’s the scoo-hoop. The title bout is coming up at Pluckett’s place, and his boy Red has been a shoo-hoo-in. Til last night, when I saw our boy shoo-hoo the shoo-in out. I saw a chance to take the title from Pluckett at last. Lots of money to be made, Flo. We can all dip our beaks. (releases Flo, sings) New bird in town-- New champ emerging! With the right urging... (to Flo) That's your concern.  38.

dialogues.speaker: OWLEONE / BATS / JOHNNY
dialogues.text: New bird in town, We got a lot to... earn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack anxiously checks his watch as the Staffbirds prep to open. He hears the elevator door open... Drenched, raggedy Dag steps out. Mack hurries to meet him

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Where ya been, you’re late..

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Mack. He struts past with unusual determination, as Mack follow INT. FLO’S DRESSING ROOM Flo’s at her mirror making up as Dag knocks and enters...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Miss, um, Flo? Is that offer still open?

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: How’s tonight? Flo smiles, stands, runs her wing through Dag’s comb, giv him a lingering kiss on the chee Mack watches from the doorway with mixed reactions -- surprise, worry, jealousy. Mostly jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: MACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You ask me, you two need a chaperone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag changes from his busboy jacket into a tux. Mack paces

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Aw no, she’s safe with me.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: It’s not her I’m worried about. Thought you was a one-hen rooster.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Well, one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: (hands him a comb) Better comb that comb. You sure you know what you’re getting into, kid? A date with 26 ain’t cheap, how are you gonna--

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you could float me a loan til payday? “I’m good for it. Mack sighs, pulls out his wallet. As he hands Dag money:  39.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Sure, kid, but is she good for you?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter, Mack, you jealous?

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Me? Jealous? Of who? Me? Come on!

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Ready, Dag? Flo's at the door, radiant in clingy gown. Dag and Mack g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocky’s riding Dag and Flo to ground level.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: All the way down, Cocky. (to Dag) I’m gonna show you a side of the city not many daybirds get to see. The underside. Cocky pulls a lever, opens a trap door. Dag and Flo drop.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Brkaaaaaaaaaaaa..... !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flo and Dag slide through the twisting pipe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And land -- BOING -- ona bigs discarded mattress in a dan cement chamber. NIGHTBIRDS flock everywhere, moving to... WATER-TAXIS bobbing on a glistening river of sewage -- a pirate ship, a fake Egyptian barge, etc. The GONDOLIERS a costumed RATS, calling to the nightclubbers...

dialogues.speaker: GONDOLIERS
dialogues.text: Set sail for the Pirates Club! Take the Ship of the Desert to the Oasis of the Sewers! Nero’s Castle, right this way! Flo and Dag board a boat shaped like a tunnel-of-love swa MUSIC UP as their little boat sails into the darkness and start a jazzy MONTAGE -- Flo and Dag’s big night out. INT. SEWER “STRIP” - NIGHT palm tree, skull-and-bones), reflect in the river of wast Dag gapes, wide-eyed, as the little swanboat bobs along between rows of neon columns to “NERO’S CASTLE”... FLASHING NEON SIGNS, bones, from the world above (pyramid IN THE BAR - a COCKTAIL BIRD serves drinks in blossom-sha cups. Flo says, give ita try: Dag dips his beak... makes yuk-face. Flo laughs and sucks her drink dry. IN THE CASINO - Dag plays roulette. He wins! As Flo hugs him, he slurps a drink -- getting a taste for it.  40.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: New bird in town, Lucky beginner...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Wow, I'm a winner, Money to_ burn! (spoken) Let it ride. Dag loses. As the stack of chips is raked away...

dialogues.speaker: _. FLO
dialogues.text: New bird in town, You got a lot to learn. IN THE ARENA - Dag and Flo sit ringside at the cockfights (Unlike real fighting cocks, our animated roosters wear boxing gloves on their wings, using their claws mostly fo fancy footwork,] Ready Red O’Reilly, the hulking rooster threw out of Birdland, is handily creaming a smaller roos Flo cheers and shouts, totally into it. Dag cringes at first... then starts to air-box, wishing he could KO Red. IN THE LOUNGE - Flo and Dag watch “COONEY & POSS, MAGICIA the Raccoon’s sawing his silent partner in half. A COCKTA BIRD flits by, Dag grabs the drinks from her tray. IN THE CASINO - Dag loses. Flo talks to the RAT CROUPIER who picks up a s aking: —-tube nearby. A camera turns its on Dag -- actual a periscope jerry-rigged from tubes and mirrors. We FOLLOW the elaborate periscope up, up, up to. DON OWLEONE’S PENTHOUSE - where the owl watches a reflect image of Dag as Bats talks into a speaking tube.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Sure, he works for us, give him as much credit as he wants. BACK IN THE CASINO - the Croupier-Rat slides a new stack chips to Dag, who can’t believe how generous everyone is. ACTION BLURS into swirls of light and faces as Dag bets - the wheel spins -- he loses --"bets -- spins... until the WHOLE CASINO is spinning along with the roulette wheel -- in a flurry of feathers, Dag passes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight out of the Hopper painting Nighthawks at the Din ZOOM IN ON THE STEPS leading up to the door -- tucked underneath them is another, much smaller diner. The name, “Nighthawks,” is painted over the window. Inside an actua NIGHTHAWK mans the grill as Flo and Dag perch at the coun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag guzzles coffee and water as he talks to Flo.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: How ya feeling, honey?  41.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: How much did I lose again? No, don’t tell me. I kept thinking I was gonna win it back.

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: You and every bird in the house. I should've stopped you sooner.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Flo, I don’t blame you. Say, you wouldn't want to Maybe... go out again?

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: And again and again? You wanna be my girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: FLO
dialogues.text: Whoa, boy, one date at a time. 1/11 be your “Girl Friday,” how’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: That’s great, Flo. You know, whatever tonight cost -- it was worth it. Touched, Flo gives him a peck on the cheek. As we PULL BA from thé window into the surrounding night:

dialogues.speaker: FLO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: New bird in town... You've got a lot to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dag’s coxcomb hangs limply over his eyes -- and the rest him looks pretty hungover, too, as he rides up with Cocky

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: Rough night, kid? (off Dag’'s “shhh,” whispers) Sorry. Rough night? Dag nods. Cocky opens the doors, and Dag steps into... nny and Bats -- who shove him back onto the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Boss wants a word with you. INT. ELEVATOR / DON OWLEONE’S PENTHOUSE The elevator doors open_to reveal Don Owleone pinning a M to the floor with one claw.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t me, I swear it wasn’t me!

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Could you give us a moment, Cocky?  42. Cocky nods, closes the doors. An awkward beat as they all wait. Dag reacts to blood-curdling MOUSE SCREAMS offstage Cocky and the bats stay deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, avanti! Cocky opens the doors. No sign of the mouse, but the Owl licking his claw.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Had to be done. He was a squealer. (then, to Dag) We meet again, my young friend. And in such a short time, you have run up a hooooo-huge debt.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Guess I got a little carried away.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: You spent like a drunken seagull.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Whatever I owe you, please, take it out of my salary. Bats slides beads on a bird toy, using it as an abacus.

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: It ain’t chicken-feed, chicky. Let’s see, minimum wage timés maximom hours, carry the six, you'll be all paid up in thirty-seven years.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: What about the vig, boss?

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Johnny, yeah, adding the interest, that’1l be -- fifty- three years. How long do roosters live anyway?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: Depends. On how quick they pay their debts. Johnny grins, revealing GLEAMING FANGS. Reaches under a w to pull out... a STEEL FILE. As he sharpens his fangs...

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do to me?

dialogues.speaker: BATS
dialogues.text: This kinda money, we gotta at least break a drumstick.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: At least. He lunges for Dag’s thigh... but before he connects, Dag loose with a pre-emptive CROW of pain.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Rawwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwkakak !  43. The sound echoes loudly, making both bats cover their ear

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY GUANO
dialogues.text: Yow! Knock it off!

dialogues.speaker: BATS AMORE
dialogues.text: We got sensitive ears! That throat-a yours is a loaded weapon.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I just don’t wanna get... fanged.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Perhaps I can suggest an alternative. He gestures a wing towards one of the Cockfighting poster

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Cockfighting?! Aw no, like I told you...

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: A lover not a fighter, yes, you seem to have loved away a lotta loot last night. And aside from the urgent question of how you'll repay us... you need to consider your own fu-hooture. Dag nods, staring into the owl’s HUGE EYES. Don Owleone’s linking gaze and mellifluous voice start to hypnotize Dag

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do yoo-hooo hope to feather the nest of Ms. Nightingale, who-hoose company and tastes are, shall we say, not fru—hoogal? Five fights and you! ve paid us off. Win the title, you’ll be roo-hoosting on a mountain of moo-hooooolah.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: (echoes, entranced) Moo-hooolah.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Yes, moo-hoolah. Now snap out of it. (SMACKS Dag with a wing-tip) Have we got a deal?

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: Sounds like an offer I can’t refuse.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: That’s the spirit.

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: I still don’t know squat about fighting.

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: You will. Cocky Cacciatore steps out of the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: DON OWLEONE
dialogues.text: Meet your trainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocky leads Dag and Mack through rubble...

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: -Just think about it before you go off ail halt- cocked, no pun intended. ~“Cock- fighting’s a brutal... scary. Mack and Dag stop short at the sight of... ROOSTERS -- sitting silently around the shadowy, overgrow playground. On the jungle-gym bars. On the swing set. On the seesaws. They’re everywhere. Just... brooding. It’s a scene straight out of Hitchcock. And like the humans in “ Birds,” Dag and Mack move past them very quietly. Then.

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: All right, lazybirds, up and at ‘em! Cocky’s shout wakes the roosters -- they weren’t brooding just sleeping, As they rustle and stretch to life, Cock points to a sign made from two other signs: “HOT WINGS GY

dialogues.speaker: COCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go, what are ya, a buncha daybirds? Dag watches wide-eyed as the other Roosters ease into the routines... chinning on the monkey-bars, weight-training the see-saws, sparring in a sandbox roped like a boxing-r

dialogues.speaker: COCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Course, most of ‘em are daybirds. They gotta gobble chicken-speed just to stay awake. But you, you’re a natural. Here, these should fit ya. He hands Dag a pair of boxing gogioves « As Mack helps fi over Dag’s wingtips, Cocky picks another piece of gear. COCKY (CONT’D) And try this on for size. Dag reacts in horror at the sight of the MUZZLE Cocky hol

dialogues.speaker: DAG
dialogues.text: .-I have to wear that?

dialogues.speaker: COCKY
dialogues.text: League rules, so you lugs don’t peck each other to death. Relax, it won’t hurt. But Dag looks anything but relaxed as Cocky buckles it on Now Paulie and Red enter the gym.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Hello... Mack.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Hello... Paulie. (Bogie) Of all the gym-joints in all the world, you had to walk into mine.  45.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
